musicalLanguage.description: A folk-pop masterpiece in 6/8 time, built on a descending chord progression that mirrors the lyrical gravity. The arpeggiated accompaniment gives it a hymn-like, meditative quality. This arrangement uses the verse section with its iconic I-V-vi-IV-V progression.
keyMoments: Bars 1-2: C to Am — the descending bass establishes the reflective mood
Bars 5-6: F to G — the harmonic lift toward the 'Hallelujah' moment
Bars 7-8: C to G — resolution and preparation to repeat
teachingGoals: Playing in 6/8 time — feeling two groups of three
Arpeggiated left-hand patterns in compound meter
Smooth melodic phrasing over a rocking accompaniment
styleTips: Feel the 6/8 as a gentle rocking motion — ONE-two-three FOUR-five-six
The left hand arpeggio should be completely even, like a lullaby
Right-hand melody floats above — sing it in your head as you play

measures.leftHand: C3:e E3:e G3:e C3:e E3:e G3:e
measures.teachingNote: C major in 6/8 — feel the two-beat rocking pattern. Each dotted quarter = one beat group.

measures.leftHand: A2:e C3:e E3:e A2:e C3:e E3:e
measures.teachingNote: A minor — the melody rises to A4 then settles back. Feel the shift to minor.

measures.leftHand: C3:e E3:e G3:e C3:e E3:e G3:e
measures.teachingNote: Back to C major — the repetition is intentional. This song is built on cycles.

measures.leftHand: A2:e C3:e E3:e A2:e C3:e E3:e
measures.teachingNote: A minor again — this time the melody drops from A4 to E4. A gentle sigh.

measures.leftHand: F2:e A2:e C3:e F2:e A2:e C3:e
measures.teachingNote: F major — the IV chord lifts the harmony. This is where the chorus feeling begins.

measures.leftHand: G2:e B2:e D3:e G2:e B2:e D3:e
measures.teachingNote: G major — the V chord. Tension building toward resolution.

measures.leftHand: C3:e E3:e G3:e C3:e E3:e G3:e
measures.teachingNote: C major — the melody peaks at C5 for the climax, then descends. The 'Hallelujah' moment.

measures.leftHand: G2:e B2:e D3:e G2:e B2:e D3:e
measures.teachingNote: G major — the phrase ends open on the V chord, pulling you back to repeat.
